text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

29A.1	The Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance is responsible for policy leadership in all management areas through the provision of a clear, integrated global management strategy and policy framework and through strengthened monitoring, evaluation and accountability mechanisms. The Department is also responsible, jointly with the Department of Operational Support, for managing the activities of the Office of Information and Communications Technology. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and decisions, including resolutions 72/266 A, 72/266 B, 72/254 and 73/281. The Department plays an integral role in realizing the Secretary-General’s management paradigm, with an emphasis on transparency, accountability and decision-making that is closer to points of delivery.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

29A.2	The strategy for 2026 includes continuing to advance the management paradigm through an integrated approach, with five interlinked pillars: the enterprise resource planning solution; programme planning, finance and budget; human resources; business transformation and accountability; and addressing racism and racial discrimination. The Department will:

(a)	Commit to new internal ways of working, including through the formulation of holistic policies and approaches that foster the achievement of tangible results, including through renewed investment in technology and a commitment to continuous improvement;
(b)	Strengthen the Organization’s resilience, including its preparedness to maintain business continuity in emergencies and to continually adapt to changing environments, risks and opportunities;

(c)	Drive results-based management policies and practices into the daily functioning and culture of the Organization, together with an integrated cycle of planning, risk and performance management, and evaluation;
(d)	Promote a culture of efficiency in the request for and use of Member States’ resources for the implementation of all Secretariat activities;

(e)	Foster greater transparency and accountability to engender greater credibility and trust in the capabilities of the United Nations as an organization, among both the Member States and the people whom it serves;

(f)	Enhance data analysis and reporting capabilities that enable real-time, user-friendly access to data to support informed decision-making and improved management of risks to achieve the objectives of the United Nations;
(g)	Create a collaborative and inclusive environment through integrated solutions and strategic partnerships throughout the United Nations system;

(h)	Work towards the implementation of a dynamic human resources strategy that achieves greater workforce diversity, supports the development and integration of skills and capabilities required to fulfil mandates and respond effectively to current and future challenges, supports managers in finding the right people, provides a strengthened learning framework and a strengthened multilingualism framework, ensures a civil and safe work environment and promotes a culture of continuous learning, innovation and improvement to actively build a better United Nations;

(i)	Address racism and racial discrimination more directly and effectively in the Secretariat by encouraging reporting; enhancing accountability, monitoring and transparency; and periodically reporting on efforts and progress towards racial diversity, equity and inclusion.

29A.3	The Department will continue to provide leadership in the development and delivery of integrated organizational management strategies, policies and models supporting a decentralized, field-focused paradigm in which managers are empowered through the enhanced delegation of authority framework. It will liaise with Member States and other external entities on management-related issues and foster coordination within the Secretariat, as well as with the funds, programmes and specialized agencies of the United Nations system, to build partnerships and promote best practices.

29A.4	Having laid the foundation for greater decentralization, the main challenge will continue to be to accelerate the culture shift required to implement in full the management paradigm of increased delegation of authority, transparency and accountability and a culture of continuous learning.

29A.5	The Department will continue to enable business transformation that leverages current and future trends in enterprise resource planning solutions. The Umoja solution and its accompanying business intelligence framework will allow the Department to respond to organizational requirements for better and more timely decision-making, enhanced accountability systems and the rapid adoption of newly identified best practices, as well as strengthened support for real-time data access, augmented and predictive analytics and planning and monitoring capabilities.

29A.6	With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Department will continue to support and work closely with all entities of the Secretariat and build partnerships, internally within the Secretariat and externally with the United Nations system, to find inclusive responses to challenges and develop innovative business models that cater to the evolving and specific requirements of each entity, with an emphasis on the field.

29A.7	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Department will represent the Secretary-General in inter-agency coordination mechanisms, including the High-level Committee on Management of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (CEB).

29A.8	With regard to the external factors, the Department considered applicable risks identified in its risk register, and, accordingly, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the planning assumption that all stakeholders will extend their full cooperation and support to the Department in implementing its mandates.

29A.9	The Department integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The Department will play a leadership role in driving the Secretary-General’s system-wide strategy on the future of work and continue to support efforts to achieve gender parity and address sexual harassment in the workplace. Furthermore, the Department will work towards the equitable geographical distribution of Member States in the Secretariat workforce and prioritize the integration of environmental sustainability and resilience management into the strategies, policies and compliance and reporting frameworks of the Organization. Through its policy leadership in these interconnected fields, the Department will foster a change in culture at all levels of the Secretariat.

29A.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Department will continue to elevate awareness of disability inclusion within it and support entities by mainstreaming disability inclusion into human resources strategy and policy, in particular in the areas of leadership, inclusiveness and organizational culture.

children.text: Evaluation activities
29A.13	An evaluation of the evaluation community of practice, completed by the Department in 2024, has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

29A.14	In response to the results of the evaluation, the Department will enhance how the evaluation community of practice serves peer exchange and learning needs, with a view to strengthening evaluation capacities and culture in the Secretariat. This will include clarifying the purpose, objectives and intended audience of the community, as well as improving the platforms for engagement and targeting activities. The Department will regularly monitor member engagement for continuous improvement.
29A.15	The following evaluations are planned for 2026:

(a)	A joint evaluation by the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, the Department of Operational Support and the Office of Information and Communications Technology on information and communications technology security, which will be completed in 2026;
(b)	An evaluation to be conducted by the Department on a topic currently under consideration.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Enterprise resource planning solution, services to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly and to the Committee for Programme and Coordination, and management advisory services
Component 1 – Enterprise resource planning solution – Objective
29A.16	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to improve the management of the Organization’s resources for its work in line with mandates.
Strategy
29A.17	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Support business transformation in the areas of programme planning, programme management, the monitoring of programme delivery, and data and business analytics by harmonizing processes and practices and using modern technology;

(b)	Support the Organization by building on its business intelligence platforms to support access to real-time data, augmented and predictive analytics, including machine learning and natural language processing, and planning capabilities;

(c)	Support, monitor and upgrade the Umoja system to meet evolving business needs through continuous improvements directed by the business and work with business areas, to translate requirements into integrated functional solutions that are built, whenever possible, through out-of-the-box solutions that have sustainable road maps and meet Umoja architectural standards.
29A.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more efficient and transparent management of the Organization’s financial, human and physical resources;
(b)	Effective and timely decision-making by management informed by advanced analytics;
(c)	Rapid adoption and application of newly identified best practices by the Organization;
(d)	The continued effective operation of the Organization and of flexible working arrangements, given that Umoja functionality will underpin the Organization’s work.
29A.30	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Improve communication on organizational and procedural aspects of meetings;
(b)	Enhance substantive, technical and secretariat support to Member States and other participants in the meetings.
29A.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the smooth conduct of meetings of the intergovernmental bodies serviced.
29A.43	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Strengthen the Organization’s resilience, including its preparedness to maintain business continuity in emergencies and to continually adapt to changing environments, risks and opportunities;
(b)	Improve the overall quality of the acquisition process and reflect those improvements in substantive policy and guidance-related recommendations, including through the use of data analytics;

(c)	Objectively analyse the facts presented in requests for a management evaluation vis-à-vis the legal framework of the Staff Regulations and Rules of the United Nations and provide the requesting staff member with a reasoned, comprehensive evaluation conveying the basis for the recommendation of the Management Advice and Evaluation Section on the case.
29A.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more resilient, agile and sustainable Organization and an innovative and thriving workforce that delivers results;
(b)	An Organization better prepared for complex and long-term emergencies;
(c)	A strengthened acquisition and asset disposal process;
(d)	The early resolution of disputes that arise from decisions taken in the Administration on a staff member’s employment;
(e)	Greater staff awareness of the internal justice system.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced stability, security and user experience and improved data-driven decision-making

29A.19	The component completed the upgrade to Umoja enhancement package 8 and transitioned from Umoja business intelligence to Umoja Analytics in 2024. The upgrade was a highly complex and multifaceted undertaking that included the migration of human capital management software, the upgrading of application software, database migration and the upgrading of hardware. The upgrade to Umoja enhancement package 8 ensures continued support from the vendor, increases resilience to security threats, improves performance, enables enhanced user experience and ensures compatibility with evolving technology. The transition to Umoja Analytics enables users to have access to a state-of-the-art analytics solution, which marks an important milestone in the Organization’s vision of fostering data democratization and promoting a culture of data-driven decision-making.
29A.20	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.2).
Table 29A.2
Performance measure

children.text: Enhanced interfaces in support of the work of the Fifth Committee and the Committee for Programme and Coordination

29A.32	In 2024, in addition to expanding the information available in Fifth Committee Place and CPC Place, the component rolled out additional modules in the e-deleGATE platform as part of an effort to consolidate e-services provided to Member States pursuant to resolution 77/335. With respect to the Fifth Committee, the e-Submit module was launched at the second part of the resumed seventy-eighth session, streamlining the process for submitting and receiving Member States’ questions through a centralized platform directly accessible by Member States, coordinators and designated Secretariat officials. With regard to appointments under the purview of the Fifth Committee, the component launched the e-Candidatures module in time for the elections held in November 2024. Feedback from surveys highlighted favourably the use of the e-Submit module and the available information on elections and appointments. Lastly, the component launched the Fifth Committee portal on iGov, adding information on Committee proceedings, including a detailed schedule of formal and informal meetings, related documentation, a live list of speakers and an overview of action taken.
29A.33	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.I).
Figure 29A.I
Performance measure: Member States’ delegates who were either “very satisfied” or “satisfied” regarding the content of Fifth Committee Place or CPC Place
(Percentage)
Consistently high level of cases pre-cleared by the Headquarters Committee on Contracts

29A.45	The Headquarters Committee on Contracts reviews and provides written advice on procurement actions to ensure that the acquisition process adheres to the procurement principles of the United Nations. In 2024, the component maintained a high level of pre-cleared cases to assist entities in meeting their operational mandates. Pre-cleared cases allow for efficient review and thus contribute to expedited procurement. The high level of pre-cleared cases resulted from establishing operational procedures and enhancing the training provided to members of the Headquarters Committee on Contracts on the review and clearance of cases.
29A.46	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.II).
Figure 29A.II
Performance measure: percentage of pre-cleared cases (annual)

children.text: Result 3: decision-making facilitated through enhancements to Member State portals – Proposed programme plan for 2026
29A.25	The component develops portals to support Member States in making informed decisions. The component strives to further enhance Member State portals based on evolving needs.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.26	The lesson for the component was the need to meet the demand from Member States for increased access to real-time and other data from enterprise resource planning applications serving as a centralized platform. In applying the lesson, the component will enhance Member State portals to foster a culture of accountability, transparency and efficiency and facilitate decision-making by Member States.

children.text: Result 3: simplified and streamlined processes and improved services for meeting participants – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.38	Supporting Member States’ deliberations through simplified and well-established processes, as well as enhanced and harmonized access to relevant information, is critical to effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.39	The lesson for the component was that streamlining and simplifying processes could further facilitate effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making by the Fifth Committee and the Committee for Programme and Coordination, as illustrated by the use of the eSpeakers module in e-deleGATE for the formal meetings of the Fifth Committee and the incorporation of that module into the iGov portal for the Committee. This simplified inscription for Member States through a single point of entry, and allowed for the provision of up-to-date live lists, indicating position of speakers, for use by the Chair and delegations, and consolidated information, including on officials introducing reports. In applying the lesson, the component will review workflows to improve the availability of information relevant to the work of the Committees on the public websites and e-deleGATE and, where necessary, work with relevant offices to consolidate and harmonize information sources to further facilitate Member States’ participation in deliberations.

29A.51	The component supports the Headquarters Committee on Contracts, which provides written advice to delegated officials on procurement action leading to the awarding or amendment of high-value contracts and ensures that the procurement process adheres to the general procurement principles of the United Nations.

children.text: Component 2 – Services to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly and to the Committee for Programme and Coordination – Objective

29A.29	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to facilitate effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making by the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly and the Committee for Programme and Coordination.
Strategy
29A.17	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Support business transformation in the areas of programme planning, programme management, the monitoring of programme delivery, and data and business analytics by harmonizing processes and practices and using modern technology;

(b)	Support the Organization by building on its business intelligence platforms to support access to real-time data, augmented and predictive analytics, including machine learning and natural language processing, and planning capabilities;

(c)	Support, monitor and upgrade the Umoja system to meet evolving business needs through continuous improvements directed by the business and work with business areas, to translate requirements into integrated functional solutions that are built, whenever possible, through out-of-the-box solutions that have sustainable road maps and meet Umoja architectural standards.
29A.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more efficient and transparent management of the Organization’s financial, human and physical resources;
(b)	Effective and timely decision-making by management informed by advanced analytics;
(c)	Rapid adoption and application of newly identified best practices by the Organization;
(d)	The continued effective operation of the Organization and of flexible working arrangements, given that Umoja functionality will underpin the Organization’s work.
29A.30	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Improve communication on organizational and procedural aspects of meetings;
(b)	Enhance substantive, technical and secretariat support to Member States and other participants in the meetings.
29A.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the smooth conduct of meetings of the intergovernmental bodies serviced.
29A.43	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Strengthen the Organization’s resilience, including its preparedness to maintain business continuity in emergencies and to continually adapt to changing environments, risks and opportunities;
(b)	Improve the overall quality of the acquisition process and reflect those improvements in substantive policy and guidance-related recommendations, including through the use of data analytics;

(c)	Objectively analyse the facts presented in requests for a management evaluation vis-à-vis the legal framework of the Staff Regulations and Rules of the United Nations and provide the requesting staff member with a reasoned, comprehensive evaluation conveying the basis for the recommendation of the Management Advice and Evaluation Section on the case.
29A.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more resilient, agile and sustainable Organization and an innovative and thriving workforce that delivers results;
(b)	An Organization better prepared for complex and long-term emergencies;
(c)	A strengthened acquisition and asset disposal process;
(d)	The early resolution of disputes that arise from decisions taken in the Administration on a staff member’s employment;
(e)	Greater staff awareness of the internal justice system.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced stability, security and user experience and improved data-driven decision-making

29A.19	The component completed the upgrade to Umoja enhancement package 8 and transitioned from Umoja business intelligence to Umoja Analytics in 2024. The upgrade was a highly complex and multifaceted undertaking that included the migration of human capital management software, the upgrading of application software, database migration and the upgrading of hardware. The upgrade to Umoja enhancement package 8 ensures continued support from the vendor, increases resilience to security threats, improves performance, enables enhanced user experience and ensures compatibility with evolving technology. The transition to Umoja Analytics enables users to have access to a state-of-the-art analytics solution, which marks an important milestone in the Organization’s vision of fostering data democratization and promoting a culture of data-driven decision-making.
29A.20	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.2).
Table 29A.2
Performance measure

Improved stability and security through upgrade activities

children.text: Enhanced interfaces in support of the work of the Fifth Committee and the Committee for Programme and Coordination

29A.32	In 2024, in addition to expanding the information available in Fifth Committee Place and CPC Place, the component rolled out additional modules in the e-deleGATE platform as part of an effort to consolidate e-services provided to Member States pursuant to resolution 77/335. With respect to the Fifth Committee, the e-Submit module was launched at the second part of the resumed seventy-eighth session, streamlining the process for submitting and receiving Member States’ questions through a centralized platform directly accessible by Member States, coordinators and designated Secretariat officials. With regard to appointments under the purview of the Fifth Committee, the component launched the e-Candidatures module in time for the elections held in November 2024. Feedback from surveys highlighted favourably the use of the e-Submit module and the available information on elections and appointments. Lastly, the component launched the Fifth Committee portal on iGov, adding information on Committee proceedings, including a detailed schedule of formal and informal meetings, related documentation, a live list of speakers and an overview of action taken.
29A.33	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.I).
Figure 29A.I
Performance measure: Member States’ delegates who were either “very satisfied” or “satisfied” regarding the content of Fifth Committee Place or CPC Place
(Percentage)
Consistently high level of cases pre-cleared by the Headquarters Committee on Contracts

29A.45	The Headquarters Committee on Contracts reviews and provides written advice on procurement actions to ensure that the acquisition process adheres to the procurement principles of the United Nations. In 2024, the component maintained a high level of pre-cleared cases to assist entities in meeting their operational mandates. Pre-cleared cases allow for efficient review and thus contribute to expedited procurement. The high level of pre-cleared cases resulted from establishing operational procedures and enhancing the training provided to members of the Headquarters Committee on Contracts on the review and clearance of cases.

children.text: Result 3: simplified and streamlined processes and improved services for meeting participants – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.38	Supporting Member States’ deliberations through simplified and well-established processes, as well as enhanced and harmonized access to relevant information, is critical to effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.39	The lesson for the component was that streamlining and simplifying processes could further facilitate effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making by the Fifth Committee and the Committee for Programme and Coordination, as illustrated by the use of the eSpeakers module in e-deleGATE for the formal meetings of the Fifth Committee and the incorporation of that module into the iGov portal for the Committee. This simplified inscription for Member States through a single point of entry, and allowed for the provision of up-to-date live lists, indicating position of speakers, for use by the Chair and delegations, and consolidated information, including on officials introducing reports. In applying the lesson, the component will review workflows to improve the availability of information relevant to the work of the Committees on the public websites and e-deleGATE and, where necessary, work with relevant offices to consolidate and harmonize information sources to further facilitate Member States’ participation in deliberations.

children.text: Result 3: recommendations of the Headquarters Committee on Contracts accepted by delegated officials – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.51	The component supports the Headquarters Committee on Contracts, which provides written advice to delegated officials on procurement action leading to the awarding or amendment of high-value contracts and ensures that the procurement process adheres to the general procurement principles of the United Nations.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.52	The lesson for the component was that concise and clear minutes allow delegated officials to better understand the Committee’s recommendations and the reasoning therefor. In applying the lesson, the component will work towards enhancing the quality of minutes by collecting feedback from the delegated officials and providing additional training to the secretaries of the Committee.
29A.53	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.IV).
Figure 29A.IV
Performance measure: percentage of recommendations accepted by delegated officials (annual)
Deliverables
29A.28	Table 29A.6 lists all deliverables of the component.
Table 29A.6
Subprogramme 1, component 1: deliverables for the period 2024–2026, by category and subcategory

table_content.text: A.	Facilitation of the intergovernmental process and expert bodies
1.	Progress report on the status of the functioning and development of the enterprise resource planning system
Substantive services for meetings (number of three-hour meetings)
2.	Meetings of the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly

children.text: Component 3 – Management advisory services – Objective

29A.42	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to advance the transparency of administrative decision-making, fairness, integrity and the resilience of the Organization to deliver on its mandates.
Strategy
29A.17	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Support business transformation in the areas of programme planning, programme management, the monitoring of programme delivery, and data and business analytics by harmonizing processes and practices and using modern technology;

(b)	Support the Organization by building on its business intelligence platforms to support access to real-time data, augmented and predictive analytics, including machine learning and natural language processing, and planning capabilities;

(c)	Support, monitor and upgrade the Umoja system to meet evolving business needs through continuous improvements directed by the business and work with business areas, to translate requirements into integrated functional solutions that are built, whenever possible, through out-of-the-box solutions that have sustainable road maps and meet Umoja architectural standards.
29A.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more efficient and transparent management of the Organization’s financial, human and physical resources;
(b)	Effective and timely decision-making by management informed by advanced analytics;
(c)	Rapid adoption and application of newly identified best practices by the Organization;
(d)	The continued effective operation of the Organization and of flexible working arrangements, given that Umoja functionality will underpin the Organization’s work.
29A.30	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Improve communication on organizational and procedural aspects of meetings;
(b)	Enhance substantive, technical and secretariat support to Member States and other participants in the meetings.
29A.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the smooth conduct of meetings of the intergovernmental bodies serviced.
29A.43	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Strengthen the Organization’s resilience, including its preparedness to maintain business continuity in emergencies and to continually adapt to changing environments, risks and opportunities;
(b)	Improve the overall quality of the acquisition process and reflect those improvements in substantive policy and guidance-related recommendations, including through the use of data analytics;

(c)	Objectively analyse the facts presented in requests for a management evaluation vis-à-vis the legal framework of the Staff Regulations and Rules of the United Nations and provide the requesting staff member with a reasoned, comprehensive evaluation conveying the basis for the recommendation of the Management Advice and Evaluation Section on the case.
29A.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A more resilient, agile and sustainable Organization and an innovative and thriving workforce that delivers results;
(b)	An Organization better prepared for complex and long-term emergencies;
(c)	A strengthened acquisition and asset disposal process;
(d)	The early resolution of disputes that arise from decisions taken in the Administration on a staff member’s employment;
(e)	Greater staff awareness of the internal justice system.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced stability, security and user experience and improved data-driven decision-making

29A.19	The component completed the upgrade to Umoja enhancement package 8 and transitioned from Umoja business intelligence to Umoja Analytics in 2024. The upgrade was a highly complex and multifaceted undertaking that included the migration of human capital management software, the upgrading of application software, database migration and the upgrading of hardware. The upgrade to Umoja enhancement package 8 ensures continued support from the vendor, increases resilience to security threats, improves performance, enables enhanced user experience and ensures compatibility with evolving technology. The transition to Umoja Analytics enables users to have access to a state-of-the-art analytics solution, which marks an important milestone in the Organization’s vision of fostering data democratization and promoting a culture of data-driven decision-making.
29A.20	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.2).
Table 29A.2
Performance measure

table_content.text: Resilience to security threats enabled through upgrade activities

Improved stability and security through upgrade activities

Improved data-driven decision-making through the transition to Umoja Analytics

children.text: Enhanced interfaces in support of the work of the Fifth Committee and the Committee for Programme and Coordination

29A.32	In 2024, in addition to expanding the information available in Fifth Committee Place and CPC Place, the component rolled out additional modules in the e-deleGATE platform as part of an effort to consolidate e-services provided to Member States pursuant to resolution 77/335. With respect to the Fifth Committee, the e-Submit module was launched at the second part of the resumed seventy-eighth session, streamlining the process for submitting and receiving Member States’ questions through a centralized platform directly accessible by Member States, coordinators and designated Secretariat officials. With regard to appointments under the purview of the Fifth Committee, the component launched the e-Candidatures module in time for the elections held in November 2024. Feedback from surveys highlighted favourably the use of the e-Submit module and the available information on elections and appointments. Lastly, the component launched the Fifth Committee portal on iGov, adding information on Committee proceedings, including a detailed schedule of formal and informal meetings, related documentation, a live list of speakers and an overview of action taken.
29A.33	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.I).
Figure 29A.I
Performance measure: Member States’ delegates who were either “very satisfied” or “satisfied” regarding the content of Fifth Committee Place or CPC Place
(Percentage)
Consistently high level of cases pre-cleared by the Headquarters Committee on Contracts

29A.45	The Headquarters Committee on Contracts reviews and provides written advice on procurement actions to ensure that the acquisition process adheres to the procurement principles of the United Nations. In 2024, the component maintained a high level of pre-cleared cases to assist entities in meeting their operational mandates. Pre-cleared cases allow for efficient review and thus contribute to expedited procurement. The high level of pre-cleared cases resulted from establishing operational procedures and enhancing the training provided to members of the Headquarters Committee on Contracts on the review and clearance of cases.
29A.46	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.II).
Figure 29A.II
Performance measure: percentage of pre-cleared cases (annual)

29A.25	The component develops portals to support Member States in making informed decisions. The component strives to further enhance Member State portals based on evolving needs.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.26	The lesson for the component was the need to meet the demand from Member States for increased access to real-time and other data from enterprise resource planning applications serving as a centralized platform. In applying the lesson, the component will enhance Member State portals to foster a culture of accountability, transparency and efficiency and facilitate decision-making by Member States.

children.text: Result 3: simplified and streamlined processes and improved services for meeting participants – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.38	Supporting Member States’ deliberations through simplified and well-established processes, as well as enhanced and harmonized access to relevant information, is critical to effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.39	The lesson for the component was that streamlining and simplifying processes could further facilitate effective and efficient deliberations and decision-making by the Fifth Committee and the Committee for Programme and Coordination, as illustrated by the use of the eSpeakers module in e-deleGATE for the formal meetings of the Fifth Committee and the incorporation of that module into the iGov portal for the Committee. This simplified inscription for Member States through a single point of entry, and allowed for the provision of up-to-date live lists, indicating position of speakers, for use by the Chair and delegations, and consolidated information, including on officials introducing reports. In applying the lesson, the component will review workflows to improve the availability of information relevant to the work of the Committees on the public websites and e-deleGATE and, where necessary, work with relevant offices to consolidate and harmonize information sources to further facilitate Member States’ participation in deliberations.

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Programme planning, finance and budget
Component 1 – Finance – Objective

29A.55	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to secure the financing of the Organization’s expenses, pursuant to Article 17 of the Charter of the United Nations, and to ensure sound, effective and efficient integrated financial management of and reporting on United Nations resources, supported by a strong internal control environment.
Strategy
29A.56	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Ensure the proper application of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, adapt policies relating to financial matters in response to emerging issues and strengthen the system of internal controls in support of the efficient management of resources in the context of the decentralized delegation of authority framework;

(b)	Provide effective support to the Committee on Contributions, ensure the timely issuance of assessments, provide up-to-date information on the status of assessed contributions and closely monitor and forecast the collection of assessments and manage cash outflows on the basis of liquidity forecasts;

(c)	Prepare International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS)-compliant financial statements for the Organization, focusing on transparency, by incorporating a financial discussion and an analysis statement, as well as ensuring that updates to accounting standards are operationalized and that all entities are appropriately guided in year-end requirements for the preparation of financial statements and are supported in the establishment, management and reporting of the extrabudgetary funds of the Organization;
(d)	Manage financial risks through sound financial processes, investment management, global cash management and global banking management;

(e)	Coordinate and manage the group health and life insurance programmes and provide services to the Advisory Board on Compensation Claims and the United Nations Claims Board, and administer related compensation payments;
(f)	Provide governance of finance master data to ensure the integrity, standardization and harmonization of data across the enterprise resource planning system;
(g)	Provide procedures, guidance and support for Umoja finance processes to ensure effective and efficient financial management.
29A.57	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Prudent financial management of the resources entrusted to the Secretariat;
(b)	A strengthened system of internal controls that supports better programme performance management and compliance with the regulatory framework;
(c)	Increased transparency and simplification of financial processes and reporting;
(d)	Effective and efficient financial procedures;
(e)	Better positioning of the Organization to respond to external shocks.

29A.69	To contribute to the objective, the component will provide strategic guidance on budgeting and financial stewardship and develop policies, methodologies and tools in that regard, in particular:

(a)	Provide strategic guidance on financial management and financing issues, especially on cross-cutting initiatives affecting field operations, including guidance on formulating human resources requirements, corporate initiatives, financial strength and liquidity and strengthening of internal controls, and timely, high-quality, simplified and action-oriented responses to managers in the field; monitor the liquidity of individual special accounts; and oversee cash-flow and operating reserves for field operations;
(b)	Provide strategic guidance on global property management and real estate services, including oversight of major construction projects and long-term capital planning;

(c)	Provide expert advice and guidance on property management and review financial data for accurate recording and for compliance with IPSAS and the established property management performance framework for Secretariat entities, and ensure the central supervision of projects, including by incorporating risk management principles and lessons learned in decision-making.

29A.70	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in client entities effectively and efficiently managing their resources within the approved levels, with improved accuracy in forecasts and proposals.
29A.82	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Issue strategic guidance on the preparation of the proposed programme budget and the proposed budget of the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals and engage with Member States from the early stages of the budget process;

(b)	Finalize and present to the legislative bodies the Secretary-General’s annual proposed programme budget and the proposed budget of the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals, the budget performance reports and other reports on budgetary matters, including statements of programme budget implications and revised programme budget proposals, in accordance with the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation and applicable resolutions of the General Assembly;

(c)	Provide information to Member States on the potential budgetary implications of draft resolutions of the General Assembly and its Main Committees, the Economic and Social Council, the Human Rights Council and other legislative organs;

(d)	Provide substantive services on programme planning and budgetary matters to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly, the Committee for Programme and Coordination and the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and provide online tools accessible to Member States in order to facilitate deliberations;

(e)	Provide strategic guidance on budgeting and financial stewardship, including on managing spending authorities, develop policies, methodologies and tools in that regard and provide advice on all budgetary matters.
29A.83	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Increased transparency and strengthened dialogue between the Secretariat and Member States;
(b)	Efficient and effective implementation of programmes while ensuring the prudent use of resources;
(c)	Improved accuracy of programme budgets.
Programme performance in 2024
Integrity of financial postings maintained during critical system enhancements

29A.58	In preparation for the release of Umoja enhancement package 8 in April 2024, the component completed multiple test activities to ensure the integrity of financial postings generated in financial ledgers for finance and non-finance processes and put in place a risk mitigation plan for all entities using Umoja to mitigate risks during the announced system blackout period.
29A.59	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.13).
Table 29A.13
Performance measure

table_content.text: Integrity of financial postings maintained throughout the Umoja upgrade
One-stop shop for construction project teams, encompassing both financial and technical advisory support

children.text: One-stop support to capital construction projects

29A.71	In 2024, the component assumed an expanded role that encompasses the finance and budget aspects of Headquarters support functions for major construction projects, in addition to its previous role of providing technical guidance and support. The component also assumed responsibility for the end-to-end process of preparing the annual progress reports of major capital projects, including servicing legislative and expert bodies during their review and approval of such reports. This streamlined workflow provided all project teams with a one-stop shop at Headquarters and also enabled the reports to be made available earlier, ensuring timely consideration and decision-making by the legislative bodies.
29A.72	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.15).

children.text: Increased visibility on overall programme budget resource requirements before the start of the main part of the General Assembly session

29A.84	A portion of the overall resources proposed by the Secretary-General for the programme budget is not known to the Member States at the time the Secretary-General introduces the proposed programme budget to the Fifth Committee, due to the revised estimates reports and statements of programme budget implications that are presented later in the main part of the General Assembly session. In 2024, the component introduced two changes in the timeline of the presentation of some resource requirements which mitigated this shortcoming. First, the component included in the proposed programme budget the estimated resource requirements related to the mandates to be renewed by the Human Rights Council during the year, rather than in the revised estimates report later in the session. Second, unlike in prior years, the recosting report was issued in September 2024 before the start of the main part of the session, in line with Assembly resolution 78/252. These changes resulted in increased visibility for Member States on the overall resources requirements of the proposed programme budget by the time the Secretary-General introduced the proposal to the Fifth Committee in mid-October.
29A.85	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VIII).
Figure 29A.VIII

Performance measure: percentage of the overall recosted programme budget resources proposed by the Secretary-General known to Member States at the time of their introduction by the Secretary-General to the Fifth Committee

Result 3: implementation of approved updates to the International Public Sector Accounting Standards and impact analysis of upcoming changes – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.64	Significant changes in IPSAS are expected in the areas of lease accounting (IPSAS 43, effective 2025) revenue (IPSAS 47, effective 2026) and transfer expenses (IPSAS 48, effective 2026), which will entail updates to existing processes through the development of corporate guidance documents, system enhancements and targeted training for affected entities. In addition, preparations will start for upcoming changes in sustainability reporting under IPSAS.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.65	The lesson for the component was the need to plan and ensure that sufficient resources are available for changes in IPSAS and ensure that appropriate guidance related to the changes is provided to entities. In applying the lesson, the component will update accounting guidance documents, enhance the Umoja system and train affected entities.

children.text: Result 3: quality and cost-efficient capital construction projects of the Organization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.77	In its resolution 79/258, the General Assembly emphasized that the Global Asset Management Policy Service should continue to be actively involved in overseeing projects to ensure the central supervision of capital projects, including risk management and alignment with lessons learned. The component identified ways to further strengthen policy guidance to entities in planning and executing major capital projects.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.78	The lesson for the component was that the completion of four major construction projects in 2024 and 2025 presented an important opportunity to systematically collect, analyse and promulgate lessons learned and best practices. In applying the lesson, the component will conduct a lessons-learned exercise and undertake a review of approaches and processes in the implementation of capital projects, with the aim of producing updated guidelines for the management of construction projects in 2026.

children.text: Result 3: enhanced budgetary information available on the Budget Information Pilot to support Member States’ decision-making – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.90	The provision of accurate and comprehensive budgetary data is a requirement for well-informed decisions by the Member States on the programme budget. The component has made information available online through the Budget Information Pilot in Umoja and has continuously increased the functionalities of the module.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.91	The lesson for the component was that the information available to Member States through the Budget Information Pilot was not always uploaded in a timely manner and was not always easy to analyse. In applying the lesson, the component will continue to enhance the content of the Budget Information Pilot while ensuring that the information is available in a timely, granular and comparable manner to inform Member States’ decision-making.
29A.92	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.22).

children.text: Component 2 – Field operations finance – Objective

29A.68	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to ensure effective and efficient deliberations by Member States on the results to which the field and other Secretariat entities contribute, and on the resources required for the work of those entities in line with their mandates, and to ensure the effective and efficient management of resources.
Strategy
29A.56	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Ensure the proper application of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, adapt policies relating to financial matters in response to emerging issues and strengthen the system of internal controls in support of the efficient management of resources in the context of the decentralized delegation of authority framework;

(b)	Provide effective support to the Committee on Contributions, ensure the timely issuance of assessments, provide up-to-date information on the status of assessed contributions and closely monitor and forecast the collection of assessments and manage cash outflows on the basis of liquidity forecasts;

(c)	Prepare International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS)-compliant financial statements for the Organization, focusing on transparency, by incorporating a financial discussion and an analysis statement, as well as ensuring that updates to accounting standards are operationalized and that all entities are appropriately guided in year-end requirements for the preparation of financial statements and are supported in the establishment, management and reporting of the extrabudgetary funds of the Organization;
(d)	Manage financial risks through sound financial processes, investment management, global cash management and global banking management;

(e)	Coordinate and manage the group health and life insurance programmes and provide services to the Advisory Board on Compensation Claims and the United Nations Claims Board, and administer related compensation payments;
(f)	Provide governance of finance master data to ensure the integrity, standardization and harmonization of data across the enterprise resource planning system;
(g)	Provide procedures, guidance and support for Umoja finance processes to ensure effective and efficient financial management.
29A.57	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Prudent financial management of the resources entrusted to the Secretariat;
(b)	A strengthened system of internal controls that supports better programme performance management and compliance with the regulatory framework;
(c)	Increased transparency and simplification of financial processes and reporting;
(d)	Effective and efficient financial procedures;
(e)	Better positioning of the Organization to respond to external shocks.

29A.69	To contribute to the objective, the component will provide strategic guidance on budgeting and financial stewardship and develop policies, methodologies and tools in that regard, in particular:

(a)	Provide strategic guidance on financial management and financing issues, especially on cross-cutting initiatives affecting field operations, including guidance on formulating human resources requirements, corporate initiatives, financial strength and liquidity and strengthening of internal controls, and timely, high-quality, simplified and action-oriented responses to managers in the field; monitor the liquidity of individual special accounts; and oversee cash-flow and operating reserves for field operations;
(b)	Provide strategic guidance on global property management and real estate services, including oversight of major construction projects and long-term capital planning;

(c)	Provide expert advice and guidance on property management and review financial data for accurate recording and for compliance with IPSAS and the established property management performance framework for Secretariat entities, and ensure the central supervision of projects, including by incorporating risk management principles and lessons learned in decision-making.

29A.70	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in client entities effectively and efficiently managing their resources within the approved levels, with improved accuracy in forecasts and proposals.
29A.82	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Issue strategic guidance on the preparation of the proposed programme budget and the proposed budget of the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals and engage with Member States from the early stages of the budget process;

(b)	Finalize and present to the legislative bodies the Secretary-General’s annual proposed programme budget and the proposed budget of the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals, the budget performance reports and other reports on budgetary matters, including statements of programme budget implications and revised programme budget proposals, in accordance with the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation and applicable resolutions of the General Assembly;

(c)	Provide information to Member States on the potential budgetary implications of draft resolutions of the General Assembly and its Main Committees, the Economic and Social Council, the Human Rights Council and other legislative organs;

(d)	Provide substantive services on programme planning and budgetary matters to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly, the Committee for Programme and Coordination and the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and provide online tools accessible to Member States in order to facilitate deliberations;

(e)	Provide strategic guidance on budgeting and financial stewardship, including on managing spending authorities, develop policies, methodologies and tools in that regard and provide advice on all budgetary matters.
29A.83	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Increased transparency and strengthened dialogue between the Secretariat and Member States;
(b)	Efficient and effective implementation of programmes while ensuring the prudent use of resources;
(c)	Improved accuracy of programme budgets.
Programme performance in 2024
Integrity of financial postings maintained during critical system enhancements

29A.58	In preparation for the release of Umoja enhancement package 8 in April 2024, the component completed multiple test activities to ensure the integrity of financial postings generated in financial ledgers for finance and non-finance processes and put in place a risk mitigation plan for all entities using Umoja to mitigate risks during the announced system blackout period.
29A.59	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.13).
Table 29A.13
Performance measure

One-stop shop for construction project teams, encompassing both financial and technical advisory support

children.text: One-stop support to capital construction projects

29A.71	In 2024, the component assumed an expanded role that encompasses the finance and budget aspects of Headquarters support functions for major construction projects, in addition to its previous role of providing technical guidance and support. The component also assumed responsibility for the end-to-end process of preparing the annual progress reports of major capital projects, including servicing legislative and expert bodies during their review and approval of such reports. This streamlined workflow provided all project teams with a one-stop shop at Headquarters and also enabled the reports to be made available earlier, ensuring timely consideration and decision-making by the legislative bodies.
29A.72	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.15).

children.text: Increased visibility on overall programme budget resource requirements before the start of the main part of the General Assembly session

29A.84	A portion of the overall resources proposed by the Secretary-General for the programme budget is not known to the Member States at the time the Secretary-General introduces the proposed programme budget to the Fifth Committee, due to the revised estimates reports and statements of programme budget implications that are presented later in the main part of the General Assembly session. In 2024, the component introduced two changes in the timeline of the presentation of some resource requirements which mitigated this shortcoming. First, the component included in the proposed programme budget the estimated resource requirements related to the mandates to be renewed by the Human Rights Council during the year, rather than in the revised estimates report later in the session. Second, unlike in prior years, the recosting report was issued in September 2024 before the start of the main part of the session, in line with Assembly resolution 78/252. These changes resulted in increased visibility for Member States on the overall resources requirements of the proposed programme budget by the time the Secretary-General introduced the proposal to the Fifth Committee in mid-October.
29A.85	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VIII).
Figure 29A.VIII

Performance measure: percentage of the overall recosted programme budget resources proposed by the Secretary-General known to Member States at the time of their introduction by the Secretary-General to the Fifth Committee
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: Finance Knowledge Gateway: an integrated digital platform and United Nations global community for Umoja finance users – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
29A.60	The component’s work contributed to 2,676 visits to the Finance Knowledge Gateway platform, which exceeded the planned target of 2,658.

Result 2: improved client experience with United Nations global payment systems – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
29A.62	The component’s work contributed to 1,828 individual clients using debit cards and digital wallets as a preferred mode of payment, which exceeded the planned target of 325 clients.
29A.63	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VI).
Figure 29A.VI
Performance measure: number of individual clients using debit cards and digital wallets as a preferred mode of payment (annual)
Result 3: implementation of approved updates to the International Public Sector Accounting Standards and impact analysis of upcoming changes – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.64	Significant changes in IPSAS are expected in the areas of lease accounting (IPSAS 43, effective 2025) revenue (IPSAS 47, effective 2026) and transfer expenses (IPSAS 48, effective 2026), which will entail updates to existing processes through the development of corporate guidance documents, system enhancements and targeted training for affected entities. In addition, preparations will start for upcoming changes in sustainability reporting under IPSAS.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.65	The lesson for the component was the need to plan and ensure that sufficient resources are available for changes in IPSAS and ensure that appropriate guidance related to the changes is provided to entities. In applying the lesson, the component will update accounting guidance documents, enhance the Umoja system and train affected entities.
29A.66	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VII).
Figure 29A.VII

children.text: Result 3: quality and cost-efficient capital construction projects of the Organization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.77	In its resolution 79/258, the General Assembly emphasized that the Global Asset Management Policy Service should continue to be actively involved in overseeing projects to ensure the central supervision of capital projects, including risk management and alignment with lessons learned. The component identified ways to further strengthen policy guidance to entities in planning and executing major capital projects.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.78	The lesson for the component was that the completion of four major construction projects in 2024 and 2025 presented an important opportunity to systematically collect, analyse and promulgate lessons learned and best practices. In applying the lesson, the component will conduct a lessons-learned exercise and undertake a review of approaches and processes in the implementation of capital projects, with the aim of producing updated guidelines for the management of construction projects in 2026.
29A.79	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.18).

children.text: Result 3: enhanced budgetary information available on the Budget Information Pilot to support Member States’ decision-making – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.90	The provision of accurate and comprehensive budgetary data is a requirement for well-informed decisions by the Member States on the programme budget. The component has made information available online through the Budget Information Pilot in Umoja and has continuously increased the functionalities of the module.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.91	The lesson for the component was that the information available to Member States through the Budget Information Pilot was not always uploaded in a timely manner and was not always easy to analyse. In applying the lesson, the component will continue to enhance the content of the Budget Information Pilot while ensuring that the information is available in a timely, granular and comparable manner to inform Member States’ decision-making.

children.text: Component 3 – Programme planning and budgeting – Objective

29A.81	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to ensure the effective and efficient deliberations by Member States on the results to which the Secretariat contributes, on the translation of mandates into programme plans and on the resources required for the work of the Secretariat in line with its mandates, and to ensure the effective and efficient management of resources and transparent reporting thereon.
Strategy
29A.56	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Ensure the proper application of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, adapt policies relating to financial matters in response to emerging issues and strengthen the system of internal controls in support of the efficient management of resources in the context of the decentralized delegation of authority framework;

(b)	Provide effective support to the Committee on Contributions, ensure the timely issuance of assessments, provide up-to-date information on the status of assessed contributions and closely monitor and forecast the collection of assessments and manage cash outflows on the basis of liquidity forecasts;

(c)	Prepare International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS)-compliant financial statements for the Organization, focusing on transparency, by incorporating a financial discussion and an analysis statement, as well as ensuring that updates to accounting standards are operationalized and that all entities are appropriately guided in year-end requirements for the preparation of financial statements and are supported in the establishment, management and reporting of the extrabudgetary funds of the Organization;
(d)	Manage financial risks through sound financial processes, investment management, global cash management and global banking management;

(e)	Coordinate and manage the group health and life insurance programmes and provide services to the Advisory Board on Compensation Claims and the United Nations Claims Board, and administer related compensation payments;
(f)	Provide governance of finance master data to ensure the integrity, standardization and harmonization of data across the enterprise resource planning system;
(g)	Provide procedures, guidance and support for Umoja finance processes to ensure effective and efficient financial management.
29A.57	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Prudent financial management of the resources entrusted to the Secretariat;
(b)	A strengthened system of internal controls that supports better programme performance management and compliance with the regulatory framework;
(c)	Increased transparency and simplification of financial processes and reporting;
(d)	Effective and efficient financial procedures;
(e)	Better positioning of the Organization to respond to external shocks.

29A.69	To contribute to the objective, the component will provide strategic guidance on budgeting and financial stewardship and develop policies, methodologies and tools in that regard, in particular:

(a)	Provide strategic guidance on financial management and financing issues, especially on cross-cutting initiatives affecting field operations, including guidance on formulating human resources requirements, corporate initiatives, financial strength and liquidity and strengthening of internal controls, and timely, high-quality, simplified and action-oriented responses to managers in the field; monitor the liquidity of individual special accounts; and oversee cash-flow and operating reserves for field operations;
(b)	Provide strategic guidance on global property management and real estate services, including oversight of major construction projects and long-term capital planning;

(c)	Provide expert advice and guidance on property management and review financial data for accurate recording and for compliance with IPSAS and the established property management performance framework for Secretariat entities, and ensure the central supervision of projects, including by incorporating risk management principles and lessons learned in decision-making.

29A.70	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in client entities effectively and efficiently managing their resources within the approved levels, with improved accuracy in forecasts and proposals.
29A.82	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Issue strategic guidance on the preparation of the proposed programme budget and the proposed budget of the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals and engage with Member States from the early stages of the budget process;

(b)	Finalize and present to the legislative bodies the Secretary-General’s annual proposed programme budget and the proposed budget of the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals, the budget performance reports and other reports on budgetary matters, including statements of programme budget implications and revised programme budget proposals, in accordance with the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, the Regulations and Rules Governing Programme Planning, the Programme Aspects of the Budget, the Monitoring of Implementation and the Methods of Evaluation and applicable resolutions of the General Assembly;

(c)	Provide information to Member States on the potential budgetary implications of draft resolutions of the General Assembly and its Main Committees, the Economic and Social Council, the Human Rights Council and other legislative organs;

(d)	Provide substantive services on programme planning and budgetary matters to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly, the Committee for Programme and Coordination and the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and provide online tools accessible to Member States in order to facilitate deliberations;

(e)	Provide strategic guidance on budgeting and financial stewardship, including on managing spending authorities, develop policies, methodologies and tools in that regard and provide advice on all budgetary matters.
29A.83	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Increased transparency and strengthened dialogue between the Secretariat and Member States;
(b)	Efficient and effective implementation of programmes while ensuring the prudent use of resources;
(c)	Improved accuracy of programme budgets.
Programme performance in 2024
Integrity of financial postings maintained during critical system enhancements

29A.58	In preparation for the release of Umoja enhancement package 8 in April 2024, the component completed multiple test activities to ensure the integrity of financial postings generated in financial ledgers for finance and non-finance processes and put in place a risk mitigation plan for all entities using Umoja to mitigate risks during the announced system blackout period.
29A.59	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.13).
Table 29A.13
Performance measure

table_content.text: Integrity of financial postings maintained throughout the Umoja upgrade
One-stop shop for construction project teams, encompassing both financial and technical advisory support

children.text: One-stop support to capital construction projects

29A.71	In 2024, the component assumed an expanded role that encompasses the finance and budget aspects of Headquarters support functions for major construction projects, in addition to its previous role of providing technical guidance and support. The component also assumed responsibility for the end-to-end process of preparing the annual progress reports of major capital projects, including servicing legislative and expert bodies during their review and approval of such reports. This streamlined workflow provided all project teams with a one-stop shop at Headquarters and also enabled the reports to be made available earlier, ensuring timely consideration and decision-making by the legislative bodies.

children.text: Increased visibility on overall programme budget resource requirements before the start of the main part of the General Assembly session

29A.84	A portion of the overall resources proposed by the Secretary-General for the programme budget is not known to the Member States at the time the Secretary-General introduces the proposed programme budget to the Fifth Committee, due to the revised estimates reports and statements of programme budget implications that are presented later in the main part of the General Assembly session. In 2024, the component introduced two changes in the timeline of the presentation of some resource requirements which mitigated this shortcoming. First, the component included in the proposed programme budget the estimated resource requirements related to the mandates to be renewed by the Human Rights Council during the year, rather than in the revised estimates report later in the session. Second, unlike in prior years, the recosting report was issued in September 2024 before the start of the main part of the session, in line with Assembly resolution 78/252. These changes resulted in increased visibility for Member States on the overall resources requirements of the proposed programme budget by the time the Secretary-General introduced the proposal to the Fifth Committee in mid-October.
29A.85	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VIII).
Figure 29A.VIII

Performance measure: percentage of the overall recosted programme budget resources proposed by the Secretary-General known to Member States at the time of their introduction by the Secretary-General to the Fifth Committee
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: Finance Knowledge Gateway: an integrated digital platform and United Nations global community for Umoja finance users – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
29A.60	The component’s work contributed to 2,676 visits to the Finance Knowledge Gateway platform, which exceeded the planned target of 2,658.
29A.61	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.V).
Figure 29A.V
Performance measure: increased use of the Finance Knowledge Gateway platform to resolve finance-related issues (annual) – (Number of site visits to the Finance Knowledge Gateway platform)
Result 2: improved client experience with United Nations global payment systems – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
29A.62	The component’s work contributed to 1,828 individual clients using debit cards and digital wallets as a preferred mode of payment, which exceeded the planned target of 325 clients.
29A.63	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VI).
Figure 29A.VI
Performance measure: number of individual clients using debit cards and digital wallets as a preferred mode of payment (annual)
Result 3: implementation of approved updates to the International Public Sector Accounting Standards and impact analysis of upcoming changes – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.64	Significant changes in IPSAS are expected in the areas of lease accounting (IPSAS 43, effective 2025) revenue (IPSAS 47, effective 2026) and transfer expenses (IPSAS 48, effective 2026), which will entail updates to existing processes through the development of corporate guidance documents, system enhancements and targeted training for affected entities. In addition, preparations will start for upcoming changes in sustainability reporting under IPSAS.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.65	The lesson for the component was the need to plan and ensure that sufficient resources are available for changes in IPSAS and ensure that appropriate guidance related to the changes is provided to entities. In applying the lesson, the component will update accounting guidance documents, enhance the Umoja system and train affected entities.
29A.66	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.VII).
Figure 29A.VII
Performance measure: number of audit recommendations related to implementation of the International Public Sector Accounting Standards (annual)

children.text: Result 3: quality and cost-efficient capital construction projects of the Organization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.77	In its resolution 79/258, the General Assembly emphasized that the Global Asset Management Policy Service should continue to be actively involved in overseeing projects to ensure the central supervision of capital projects, including risk management and alignment with lessons learned. The component identified ways to further strengthen policy guidance to entities in planning and executing major capital projects.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.78	The lesson for the component was that the completion of four major construction projects in 2024 and 2025 presented an important opportunity to systematically collect, analyse and promulgate lessons learned and best practices. In applying the lesson, the component will conduct a lessons-learned exercise and undertake a review of approaches and processes in the implementation of capital projects, with the aim of producing updated guidelines for the management of construction projects in 2026.

children.text: Result 3: enhanced budgetary information available on the Budget Information Pilot to support Member States’ decision-making – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.90	The provision of accurate and comprehensive budgetary data is a requirement for well-informed decisions by the Member States on the programme budget. The component has made information available online through the Budget Information Pilot in Umoja and has continuously increased the functionalities of the module.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.91	The lesson for the component was that the information available to Member States through the Budget Information Pilot was not always uploaded in a timely manner and was not always easy to analyse. In applying the lesson, the component will continue to enhance the content of the Budget Information Pilot while ensuring that the information is available in a timely, granular and comparable manner to inform Member States’ decision-making.
29A.92	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.22).
Table 29A.22
