children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Human resources
Component 1 – Global strategy and policy – Objective

29A.94	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to ensure a decentralized, agile, field-focused management paradigm for the effective and transparent management of human resources and a high-performing, diverse and engaged workforce.
Strategy

29A.95	To contribute to the objective, the component will further develop, update and enhance the recruitment system to ensure that it is effective, fair, efficient and agile and to enable the United Nations to have a diverse workforce and foster a culture of ethics, integrity, transparency and accountability in the Organization. Specifically, the component will:
(a)	Steer efforts for equitable geographical distribution under the system of desirable ranges, in accordance with General Assembly resolution 77/278;

(b)	Provide strategic guidance on human resources supported by an enabling policy framework to fulfil entities’ mandates, in which team, individual and organizational performance are aligned and human resources risks are transparently and effectively managed; and foster innovation as a means of improving programmatic delivery of human resources in support of cultural change across the Organization;

(c)	Establish strategic policy imperatives anchored in guidance and feedback from entities, in particular from the field, continue to provide authoritative policy interpretation to ensure consistency, fairness and the equitable treatment of staff in the global Secretariat, and oversee the setting of salaries and benefits for locally recruited staff members by applying methodologies established by the International Civil Service Commission;

(d)	Actively engage on all aspects of relations between staff and management and work with other organizations of the United Nations common system on salaries and allowances to advance the work of the High-level Committee on Management and the Human Resources Network of CEB, and through the International Civil Service Commission, including by leading the implementation of the United Nations workplace mental health and well-being strategy across the United Nations system;

(e)	Further develop efforts towards mutual recognition over time, which calls for entities within the United Nations common system to operate according to the principle of mutual recognition of best practices in terms of policies and procedures, and lead efforts to enhance harmonization and improve efficiency in the United Nations system;

(f)	Improve talent management in the Organization and, in particular, work towards implementing the new approach to mobility and organizational learning, developing a new staff selection system that is effective, fair, efficient and agile, and that enables the Organization to have a diverse workforce, adopting approaches that incorporate new values and behaviours into talent management and strengthening the performance management framework;

(g)	In line with action 45 (a) of the Pact for the Future, engage in talent management actions, such as the upskilling and reskilling of staff or the creation of new job profiles, to enable the workforce of the Organization to meet the future demands identified through strategic workforce planning, and to attract and retain the best talent with due regard to geographical representation and gender parity priorities;
(h)	Provide workforce data to external stakeholders for analyses of staff and affiliated personnel demographics, Member State representation and workforce trends.
29A.96	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A culture of staff mobility that accelerates the mobility process across the Organization, in particular movements between Headquarters and field duty stations;

(b)	Talent acquisition focused on current workforce capability needs, anticipation of future needs and enhancement of existing talent through learning and development, mobility and effective performance management and career satisfaction support;
(c)	Gender parity at all levels;

(d)	Recruitment of staff on as wide a geographical basis as possible, a reduced number of unrepresented and underrepresented Member States, and progress made on bringing as many Member States as possible within their desirable range.
29A.108	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Deploy and use a global case management system and identify lessons learned, including in relation to critical incidents involving serious reputational risks affecting the Organization’s core values and norms, and develop tools and guidance material for senior leaders;

(b)	Engage in capacity-building, including through the online information-sharing platform ALD Connect, direct outreach to senior managers and the ongoing development of tools and guidance materials to support senior managers in carrying out their responsibilities and exercising their authority;

(c)	Review disciplinary matters for sanctioning purposes, represent the Secretary-General before the United Nations Dispute Tribunal regarding appeals against administrative decisions, continue to expand screening for integrity for the Secretariat, and continue to review and update policies relating to the conduct of personnel.
29A.109	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced oversight across the Secretariat and monitoring of matters that affect the reputation of the Organization, and the timely review and handling of misconduct matters;
(b)	Well-informed decision-making by senior managers in relation to the management of personnel;
(c)	An enhanced culture of individual accountability.
Programme performance in 2024
Business continuity and staff safety and well-being through human resources support in relation to emergencies

29A.97	In 2024, the component provided support for staff members in response to emergencies in Haiti, Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territory, Lebanon, the Sudan and the Syrian Arab Republic. Support was provided to relevant entities through policy advice and the development of the CEB Human Resources Network administrative guidelines. The guidelines contained a summary of the human resources policy, conditions of service and compensation measures applicable to both internationally and locally recruited staff members in affected duty stations. The guidelines were developed on the basis of input from Secretariat entities, United Nations common system organizations and staff federations. They were aimed at ensuring a harmonized and consistent approach at the country level across United Nations common system organizations and finding common solutions to concerns raised in order to preserve business continuity. The component provided ongoing authoritative policy advice and interpretation on field-related allowances and benefits. It actively supported United Nations personnel working in challenging environments by monitoring conditions and addressing their needs. This included measures such as the implementation of special temporary hardship classifications, danger pay, non-family service allowances, and rest and recuperation cycles to ensure fair compensation and staff well-being.
29A.98	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.24).
Table 29A.24
Performance measure

table_content.text: Business continuity and staff safety and well-being in emergency situations were ensured
Senior managers consulted the Administrative Law Division with increased frequency prior to taking sensitive conduct-related management decisions
Senior managers had a clear understanding of the administration of justice system and framework for ascertaining risks related to sensitive decisions

Senior managers regularize the practice of utilizing available tools prior to taking sensitive conduct-related decisions, resulting in strengthened decision-making and reduced risk to the Organization

children.text: Improved accountability for conduct and discipline matters

29A.110	The subprogramme contributed to and supported initiatives to strengthen accountability in matters related to conduct and discipline across the Secretariat. In response to General Assembly resolutions 77/280 and 78/253, efforts were accelerated to expand the scope of ClearCheck to include all substantiated forms of misconduct, in addition to sexual harassment and sexual exploitation and abuse, in close consultation with stakeholders. The risk management toolkit was expanded to include a focus on an integrated, regional and field-based approach, data analytics was used as a risk management tool, and a digital risk assessment tool was developed.
29A.111	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.28).

Performance measure: number of unrepresented and underrepresented Member States in the desirable ranges system (annual)
Result 3: a fair, effective, efficient and agile staff selection system – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.103	The component continues its efforts to attract, select and engage talented individuals who provide for the modern and future-oriented skills and capabilities needed to support the evolving work of the United Nations. In improving the staff selection system, paramount consideration is given to the necessity of securing the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity for building a future-ready and agile workforce, while realizing the goal of having a diverse staff. It will ensure that the staff selection system includes practices and processes that are effective, fair, efficient and agile.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.104	The lesson for the component, based on comprehensive recruitment analyses, was the need to address systemic and structural issues in the current recruitment process to make progress towards securing the skills and capabilities needed for a future-ready workforce and achieving equitable geographical distribution. In applying the lesson, the component will work on the multi-year staff selection 2.0 programme. This initiative is aimed at establishing fair, efficient, effective and agile recruitment practices and processes aligned with securing the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity as stated in Article 101 of the Charter of the United Nations. The staff selection 2.0 programme includes dedicated projects to update and create future-oriented, inclusive and attractive job profiles to recruit the talented individuals needed for the jobs of today and tomorrow; implement modern and efficient screening and assessment methods, and redefine roles and responsibilities for recruiters; and establish a data platform to allow real-time monitoring of the recruitment system’s accuracy, fairness and efficiency.
29A.105	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.26).

children.text: Result 2: adjustments to the Secretariat’s policy framework and management practices facilitated by United Nations Dispute Tribunal judgments – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
29A.114	The component’s work contributed to 91 per cent of administrative decisions being upheld, which exceeded the planned target of 75 per cent.
29A.115	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.X).
Figure 29A.X
Performance measure: percentage of administrative decisions (non-disciplinary) of the United Nations Dispute Tribunal that are upheld (annual)
Note: The actual figure for 2023 reflects updated data.
Result 3: enhanced decision-making capacity of senior leadership in handling conduct and discipline matters – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.116	Leadership responsibility for creating and maintaining a harmonious work environment is built on the premise that senior-level decision makers are cognizant of the regulatory framework in place for prohibited conduct (as defined in the Secretary-General’s bulletin on addressing discrimination, harassment, including sexual harassment, and abuse of authority (ST/SGB/2019/8)) and of their specific roles and responsibilities in achieving this goal. To this end, as part of its support and advisory services, the component provides induction sessions to newly recruited senior leaders, offering a comprehensive overview of the formal and informal parts of the internal justice system.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.117	The lesson for the component was that the induction sessions that the component currently provides to incoming leaders could be strengthened to include more practical information on handling conduct and discipline matters. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will overhaul the induction sessions to provide heads of entity with information that would assist them in handling the common types of prohibited cases that they may face on a day-to-day basis and the types of prompt action they could take to prevent or mitigate the risk of prohibited conduct within the entity, in particular in sensitive areas involving harassment, discrimination and abuse of authority under ST/SGB/2019/8. In addition, the session will expressly cover the duty of care owed to victims of prohibited conduct and the specific tools and measures available to them.

children.text: Component 2 – Administrative law – Objective
29A.107	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to strengthen accountability in line with the standards of conduct by all categories of personnel.
Strategy

29A.95	To contribute to the objective, the component will further develop, update and enhance the recruitment system to ensure that it is effective, fair, efficient and agile and to enable the United Nations to have a diverse workforce and foster a culture of ethics, integrity, transparency and accountability in the Organization. Specifically, the component will:
(a)	Steer efforts for equitable geographical distribution under the system of desirable ranges, in accordance with General Assembly resolution 77/278;

(b)	Provide strategic guidance on human resources supported by an enabling policy framework to fulfil entities’ mandates, in which team, individual and organizational performance are aligned and human resources risks are transparently and effectively managed; and foster innovation as a means of improving programmatic delivery of human resources in support of cultural change across the Organization;

(c)	Establish strategic policy imperatives anchored in guidance and feedback from entities, in particular from the field, continue to provide authoritative policy interpretation to ensure consistency, fairness and the equitable treatment of staff in the global Secretariat, and oversee the setting of salaries and benefits for locally recruited staff members by applying methodologies established by the International Civil Service Commission;

(d)	Actively engage on all aspects of relations between staff and management and work with other organizations of the United Nations common system on salaries and allowances to advance the work of the High-level Committee on Management and the Human Resources Network of CEB, and through the International Civil Service Commission, including by leading the implementation of the United Nations workplace mental health and well-being strategy across the United Nations system;

(e)	Further develop efforts towards mutual recognition over time, which calls for entities within the United Nations common system to operate according to the principle of mutual recognition of best practices in terms of policies and procedures, and lead efforts to enhance harmonization and improve efficiency in the United Nations system;

(f)	Improve talent management in the Organization and, in particular, work towards implementing the new approach to mobility and organizational learning, developing a new staff selection system that is effective, fair, efficient and agile, and that enables the Organization to have a diverse workforce, adopting approaches that incorporate new values and behaviours into talent management and strengthening the performance management framework;

(g)	In line with action 45 (a) of the Pact for the Future, engage in talent management actions, such as the upskilling and reskilling of staff or the creation of new job profiles, to enable the workforce of the Organization to meet the future demands identified through strategic workforce planning, and to attract and retain the best talent with due regard to geographical representation and gender parity priorities;
(h)	Provide workforce data to external stakeholders for analyses of staff and affiliated personnel demographics, Member State representation and workforce trends.
29A.96	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A culture of staff mobility that accelerates the mobility process across the Organization, in particular movements between Headquarters and field duty stations;

(b)	Talent acquisition focused on current workforce capability needs, anticipation of future needs and enhancement of existing talent through learning and development, mobility and effective performance management and career satisfaction support;
(c)	Gender parity at all levels;

(d)	Recruitment of staff on as wide a geographical basis as possible, a reduced number of unrepresented and underrepresented Member States, and progress made on bringing as many Member States as possible within their desirable range.
29A.108	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Deploy and use a global case management system and identify lessons learned, including in relation to critical incidents involving serious reputational risks affecting the Organization’s core values and norms, and develop tools and guidance material for senior leaders;

(b)	Engage in capacity-building, including through the online information-sharing platform ALD Connect, direct outreach to senior managers and the ongoing development of tools and guidance materials to support senior managers in carrying out their responsibilities and exercising their authority;

(c)	Review disciplinary matters for sanctioning purposes, represent the Secretary-General before the United Nations Dispute Tribunal regarding appeals against administrative decisions, continue to expand screening for integrity for the Secretariat, and continue to review and update policies relating to the conduct of personnel.
29A.109	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced oversight across the Secretariat and monitoring of matters that affect the reputation of the Organization, and the timely review and handling of misconduct matters;
(b)	Well-informed decision-making by senior managers in relation to the management of personnel;
(c)	An enhanced culture of individual accountability.
Programme performance in 2024
Business continuity and staff safety and well-being through human resources support in relation to emergencies

29A.97	In 2024, the component provided support for staff members in response to emergencies in Haiti, Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territory, Lebanon, the Sudan and the Syrian Arab Republic. Support was provided to relevant entities through policy advice and the development of the CEB Human Resources Network administrative guidelines. The guidelines contained a summary of the human resources policy, conditions of service and compensation measures applicable to both internationally and locally recruited staff members in affected duty stations. The guidelines were developed on the basis of input from Secretariat entities, United Nations common system organizations and staff federations. They were aimed at ensuring a harmonized and consistent approach at the country level across United Nations common system organizations and finding common solutions to concerns raised in order to preserve business continuity. The component provided ongoing authoritative policy advice and interpretation on field-related allowances and benefits. It actively supported United Nations personnel working in challenging environments by monitoring conditions and addressing their needs. This included measures such as the implementation of special temporary hardship classifications, danger pay, non-family service allowances, and rest and recuperation cycles to ensure fair compensation and staff well-being.
29A.98	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.24).
Table 29A.24
Performance measure

Senior managers regularize the practice of utilizing available tools prior to taking sensitive conduct-related decisions, resulting in strengthened decision-making and reduced risk to the Organization

children.text: Improved accountability for conduct and discipline matters

29A.110	The subprogramme contributed to and supported initiatives to strengthen accountability in matters related to conduct and discipline across the Secretariat. In response to General Assembly resolutions 77/280 and 78/253, efforts were accelerated to expand the scope of ClearCheck to include all substantiated forms of misconduct, in addition to sexual harassment and sexual exploitation and abuse, in close consultation with stakeholders. The risk management toolkit was expanded to include a focus on an integrated, regional and field-based approach, data analytics was used as a risk management tool, and a digital risk assessment tool was developed.

Result 3: a fair, effective, efficient and agile staff selection system – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.103	The component continues its efforts to attract, select and engage talented individuals who provide for the modern and future-oriented skills and capabilities needed to support the evolving work of the United Nations. In improving the staff selection system, paramount consideration is given to the necessity of securing the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity for building a future-ready and agile workforce, while realizing the goal of having a diverse staff. It will ensure that the staff selection system includes practices and processes that are effective, fair, efficient and agile.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.104	The lesson for the component, based on comprehensive recruitment analyses, was the need to address systemic and structural issues in the current recruitment process to make progress towards securing the skills and capabilities needed for a future-ready workforce and achieving equitable geographical distribution. In applying the lesson, the component will work on the multi-year staff selection 2.0 programme. This initiative is aimed at establishing fair, efficient, effective and agile recruitment practices and processes aligned with securing the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity as stated in Article 101 of the Charter of the United Nations. The staff selection 2.0 programme includes dedicated projects to update and create future-oriented, inclusive and attractive job profiles to recruit the talented individuals needed for the jobs of today and tomorrow; implement modern and efficient screening and assessment methods, and redefine roles and responsibilities for recruiters; and establish a data platform to allow real-time monitoring of the recruitment system’s accuracy, fairness and efficiency.

29A.114	The component’s work contributed to 91 per cent of administrative decisions being upheld, which exceeded the planned target of 75 per cent.
29A.115	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.X).
Figure 29A.X
Performance measure: percentage of administrative decisions (non-disciplinary) of the United Nations Dispute Tribunal that are upheld (annual)
Note: The actual figure for 2023 reflects updated data.
Result 3: enhanced decision-making capacity of senior leadership in handling conduct and discipline matters – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.116	Leadership responsibility for creating and maintaining a harmonious work environment is built on the premise that senior-level decision makers are cognizant of the regulatory framework in place for prohibited conduct (as defined in the Secretary-General’s bulletin on addressing discrimination, harassment, including sexual harassment, and abuse of authority (ST/SGB/2019/8)) and of their specific roles and responsibilities in achieving this goal. To this end, as part of its support and advisory services, the component provides induction sessions to newly recruited senior leaders, offering a comprehensive overview of the formal and informal parts of the internal justice system.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.117	The lesson for the component was that the induction sessions that the component currently provides to incoming leaders could be strengthened to include more practical information on handling conduct and discipline matters. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will overhaul the induction sessions to provide heads of entity with information that would assist them in handling the common types of prohibited cases that they may face on a day-to-day basis and the types of prompt action they could take to prevent or mitigate the risk of prohibited conduct within the entity, in particular in sensitive areas involving harassment, discrimination and abuse of authority under ST/SGB/2019/8. In addition, the session will expressly cover the duty of care owed to victims of prohibited conduct and the specific tools and measures available to them.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Business transformation and accountability
Objective

29A.120	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure a results-oriented, data-driven, agile Organization that is efficient, accountable, transparent, compliant and driven by lessons learned and continuous improvements.
Strategy
29A.121	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Focus on simplifying the Organization’s systems of accountability by evaluating overall organizational performance trends, assessing the alignment of roles and responsibilities and monitoring the exercise of delegated authority, monitoring the senior managers’ compacts, mainstreaming the use of evaluation as part of the programme planning cycle, and coordinating the Secretariat’s interaction with oversight bodies and identifying trends in their recommendations;

(b)	Carry out capacity-building activities to support all United Nations entities in identifying, assessing, evaluating and controlling risk, using an enterprise risk management approach, and support the achievement of mandated programmatic results by training all entities in results-based management;

(c)	Support the implementation of the data strategy of the Secretariat, enable entities to have access to management data from Secretariat systems and to gain access to or design analytical tools supporting data-driven decision-making, and lead and coordinate a portfolio of business transformation and innovation projects.
29A.122	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A reinforced accountability culture in the Organization in the areas of risk awareness, monitoring performance and the exercise of delegated authority;
(b)	Greater use of enterprise data and data analytics in decision-making and programme delivery;
(c)	Teams across the Secretariat adopting agile methodology and innovation and strengthening new collaboration practices using online platforms.
Programme performance in 2024
Risk management transformed through the Umoja enterprise risk management module

29A.123	The Secretary-General, in his report on shifting the management paradigm in the United Nations: ensuring a better future for all (A/72/492), highlighted that effective risk management is a fundamental aspect of managerial responsibility and accountability at all levels, as it safeguards the delivery of the Organization’s mandate. To embed enterprise risk management as a vital management tool across the Secretariat, the Umoja enterprise risk management module was developed and implemented in several phases, commencing in October 2021. As a key enabler of a strong accountability system, the module strengthens enterprise risk management by enhancing the quality of risk assessments, supporting the development of effective risk mitigation plans and improving integration between risk management and internal controls. It also facilitates robust monitoring of evolving risk profiles at both the corporate and entity levels. Furthermore, its data analytics capabilities provide valuable insights for analysing the Secretariat’s overall risk profile.

29A.124	The transition from “paper-based” risk registers to the automated module was initiated in 2021 with a group of seven entities. By 31 December 2024, the module had been successfully rolled out to 51 of the 57 entities selected for the implementation of enterprise risk management. Additional entities are scheduled to complete the transition in 2025.

29A.125	The Umoja enterprise risk management module will contribute towards strengthening the Organization's first and second lines of defence, ensuring that risk identification and management become standard and integral practices at all levels.
29A.126	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.XI).
Figure 29A.XI
Performance measures: percentage of entities utilizing the Umoja enterprise risk management module (annual)

children.text: Result 3: enhanced data-driven decision-making through continuous improvement of the management dashboard – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.131	Improved access to, and leveraging of, key corporate data are critical for more results-driven organizational performance. Through the management dashboard platform, the subprogramme has enabled targeted access to business intelligence data to support programme managers in using evidence-based systems for improved decision-making and performance.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.132	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need for continuous improvement to the management dashboard, on the basis of client-identified needs. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will expand the scope of reports and functionalities within the management dashboard to support evidence-based decision-making, including by integrating Board of Auditors recommendations, organizational performance indicators, an enterprise risk management dashboard and reports on analytics related to the recruitment pipeline. In parallel, the initiative will optimize the user experience design and evaluate strategies to expand its internal user base.
29A.133	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 29A.XII).

children.text: Subprogramme 5 – Addressing racism in the workplace
Objective

29A.135	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure a workplace free from racism and racial discrimination, in which every staff member feels valued and respected and is treated with dignity.
Strategy
29A.136	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Implement the strategic action plan by driving progress towards a racism-free Secretariat through oversight, coordination and monitoring of all anti-racism initiatives;
(b)	Review and address existing or potential racial bias in institutional policies and practices and promote data transparency;
(c)	Promote advocacy, awareness-raising and training programmes to support personnel and improve organizational culture with regard to racism;

(d)	Strengthen accountability mechanisms within the Organization by providing expertise to United Nations system entities on current practices and developments relating to the investigation and adjudication of racial discrimination matters;
(e)	Address institutional and systemic racism by putting in place leadership accountability mechanisms;

(f)	Advocate for system-wide anti-racism initiatives by collaborating and building synergies with United Nations system entities and other relevant partners to share best practices and lessons learned.
29A.137	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	An institutionalized anti-racism culture fully embedded in policies, procedures and practices within the Organization, ensuring zero tolerance for racism and racial discrimination;
(b)	The empowerment and equitable racial representation of staff at all levels and categories within the Organization;
(c)	Increased trust in internal processes of administration to mediate, investigate and adjudicate fairly allegations of racism and provide racial justice.
Programme performance in 2024
An enabling environment to address racism in the Organization

29A.138	Following the establishment of the Anti-Racism Office in December 2023, the subprogramme continued to implement the series of initiatives to address interpersonal, institutional and systemic forms of racism in the Organization. The subprogramme launched an online tracking tool to monitor the implementation of the strategic action plan contained in the report of the Secretary-General on addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the United Nations Secretariat (A/76/771) by partner departments and offices, and conducted quarterly meetings to empower and mobilize the global network of anti-racism advocates. The subprogramme organized regular awareness-raising activities in different formats: town halls, live talks, dialogues, brown bag discussions and training courses on anti-racism, to inform, educate and equip personnel with practical tools. The subprogramme has commenced making alignments in the staff selection process, specifically with projects to support “blind-hiring” practices, require “diversity in hiring panels” and update training and guidance provided to hiring teams on reducing racial bias in recruitment. The subprogramme also intensified advocacy and strengthened processes with stakeholders involved in the administration of justice to create a safe environment for reporting allegations of racism, expediting investigations and enhancing racial justice mechanisms.
29A.139	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 29A.35).
Table 29A.35
Performance measure

children.text: Result 2: improved institutional transparency on diversity – Proposed programme plan for 2026

29A.142	The subprogramme’s work contributes to the improvement of institutional transparency through the review and reform of policies and practices. In 2024, the subprogramme finalized a background paper on the importance of collecting race-related data.
Lessons learned and planned change

29A.143	The lesson for the subprogramme was the importance of promoting data transparency in institutional policies and practices. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will focus on building a staff-facing dashboard on staff composition and movements of personnel. The subprogramme will also be able to collect race-related data from staff and job applicants on a voluntary basis for the purpose of understanding workforce composition. The subprogramme will further strengthen the Organization’s staff selection processes by working towards mandating diversity in selection panels, promoting blind-hiring practices and building common assessment methods.

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Other changes
29A.149	As shown in tables 29A.42 (1) and 29A.43 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $1,461,600, as follows:
(a)	Lower rates for information and communications technology services (decrease of $183,300) under contractual services ($134,000) and general operating expenses ($49,300):
(i)	Executive direction and management (decrease of $15,900);
(ii)	Subprogramme 1, component 2, Services to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly and to the Committee for Programme and Coordination (decrease of $5,800);
(iii)	Subprogramme 1, component 3, Management advisory services (decrease of $12,200);
(iv)	Subprogramme 2, component 1, Finance (decrease of $24,300);
(v)	Subprogramme 2, component 2, Field operations finance (decrease of $5,100);
(vi)	Subprogramme 2, component 3, Programme planning and budgeting (decrease of $26,800);
(vii)	Subprogramme 3, component 1, Global strategy and policy (decrease of $41,400);
(viii)	Subprogramme 3, component 2, Administrative law (decrease of $13,200);
(ix)	Subprogramme 4, Business transformation and accountability (decrease of $25,200);
(x)	Subprogramme 5, Addressing racism in the workplace (decrease of $5,800);
(xi)	Programme support (decrease of $7,600);

(b)	A decrease of $18,100 under grants and contributions, reflecting the regular budget share (15 per cent of $120,400) under subprogramme 1, component 1, Enterprise resource planning solution, of lower rates for information and communications technology services and rental of premises, as explained in paragraph 29A.163 (a) below;

(c)	The cost-neutral conversion of six long-term temporary positions to posts, reflecting an increase of $1,257,800 under posts, offset by a decrease of $1,257,800 under other staff costs under subprogramme 1, component 3, Management advisory services (Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5), Management and Programme Analyst (P-4), Administrative Assistant (General Service (Other Level)) and Legal Officer (P-4)) and subprogramme 3, component 2, Administrative law (Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5) and Legal Officer (P-3)), as explained in annex II;

(d)	The cost-neutral redeployment of resources within and between subprogrammes and components, due mainly to the realignment of resources for software licences and subscriptions under contractual services (decrease of $47,900), general operating expenses (decrease of $7,200), supplies and materials (decrease of $6,900) and furniture and equipment (increase of $65,000), under executive direction and management (decrease of $600), subprogramme 1, component 3, Management advisory services (decrease of $400), subprogramme 2, component 1, Finance (increase of $2,200), subprogramme 2, component 2, Field operations finance (increase of $200), subprogramme 3, component 1, Global strategy and policy (decrease of $300), subprogramme 3, component 2, Administrative law (increase of $100) and subprogramme 5, Addressing racism in the workplace (decrease of $1,200);
(e)	Other changes (increase of $1,663,000) under:

(i)	Subprogramme 1, component 1, Enterprise resource planning solution (increase of $19,400). The increase under grants and contributions reflects the regular budget share (15 per cent) of the annual maintenance costs for the United Nations digital identification project ($129,300), as explained in paragraph 29A.163 (b) below;
(ii)	Subprogramme 2, component 1, Finance (increase of $418,600). The increases are as follows:

a.	Increases totalling $286,800 under posts ($284,200), contractual services ($1,300), general operating expenses ($1,000) and furniture and equipment ($300) reflect the conversion from extrabudgetary resources of a D-1 post of Chief of Service to posts, as explained in annex II, and associated common services costs;

b.	Increases totalling $131,800 comprise an increase under contractual services ($8,700), which reflects the regular budget share of the increase in costs for the finance master data maintenance team, and an increase under furniture and equipment ($123,100), which would provide for mandatory upgrades to the payment system/network ($67,100) and the increased cost of the investment system ($56,000);

(iii) 	Subprogramme 2, component 3, Programme planning and budgeting (increase of $25,000). The increase under travel of staff reflects requirements to support entities in conducting the annual spending reviews;

(iv)	Subprogramme 3, component 1, Global strategy and policy (increase of $1,200,000). The increases under consultants ($60,000) and contractual services ($1,140,000) are needed for the staff selection 2.0 programme, which will update the staff selection system, as endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 77/278. The additional resources would fund system updates and projects related to generic job profiles, assessment tools and data visualization dashboards.
Other assessed resources

29A.150	As reflected in tables 29A.42 (2) and 29A.43 (2), other assessed resources amount to $63,897,400. The resources would complement regular budget resources and provide for the requirements indicated in the report of the Secretary-General on the budget for the support account for peacekeeping operations for 2025/26 (A/79/783).
Extrabudgetary resources

29A.151	As reflected in tables 29A.42 (3) and 29A.43 (3), extrabudgetary resources amount to $38,089,100. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 131 posts to perform, among other things, system-wide jointly financed activities relating to local salary surveys and personnel mental health and well-being, activities relating to personnel conduct and discipline, as well as in support of victims of sexual exploitation and abuse, activities to backstop operations funded from central programme support costs, and activities to backstop operations funded from cost recovery. In addition, financial resources from central programme support costs would also fund the extrabudgetary resources share of the Umoja enterprise resource planning solution (including business support resources).

29A.152	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
Executive direction and management

29A.153	The executive direction and management component comprises the Office of the Under-Secretary-General, including the Inter-Agency and Intergovernmental Service, the Office of the Controller and the Office of the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Resources.

29A.154	The Under-Secretary-General for Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance is responsible for the overall direction and management of the Department and for providing the Secretary-General strategic advice on management issues. The Under-Secretary-General represents the Secretary-General on management issues before relevant expert and intergovernmental bodies, such as the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and the Fifth Committee, the International Civil Service Commission and inter-agency coordination mechanisms, including the High-level Committee on Management of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination, and in the conduct of staff-management consultations. The Under-Secretary-General oversees and provides direction to the Assistant Secretary-General for Programme Planning, Finance and Budget, Controller; the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Resources; the Director of the Business Transformation and Accountability Division; and the Director of the Enterprise Resource Planning Solution Division. The Under-Secretary-General provides management oversight support to the Director of the Anti-Racism Office and, with the Under-Secretary-General for Operational Support, provides direction and strategic guidance to the Assistant Secretary-General, Chief Information Technology Officer.

29A.155	The Office of the Under-Secretary-General provides leadership in the development and delivery of integrated organizational management strategies, policies and models that support a decentralized, field-focused paradigm in which managers are empowered through the new enhanced delegation of authority framework. It provides direction to take advantage of lessons learned and innovative methods to ensure continuous management improvements to meet evolving requirements throughout the Secretariat. It liaises with Member States and other external entities on management-related issues and fosters coordination internally within the Secretariat, as well as externally with the funds, programmes and specialized agencies of the United Nations system, to build partnerships and promote best practices.

29A.156	The Under-Secretary-General is assisted by the Controller, who provides strategic and policy leadership on all planning, programming, budgetary and financial matters and on the administration of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations, and by the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Resources, who provides strategic leadership for the simplified and streamlined human resources policy framework and the mainstreaming of a gender perspective, equitable geographical distribution and accessibility into all facets of the work of the Organization through integrated strategies and policies. Working together closely under the guidance of the Under-Secretary-General, the Controller and the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Resources provide leadership in adapting strategies and policies to support new and innovative business models and enable managers to be more effective and agile in the delivery of their programmes.

29A.157	The Controller represents the Secretary-General in the committees of the General Assembly, the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions, the Committee for Programme and Coordination and the Independent Audit Advisory Committee in the presentation of all programme and budget documents, including those relating to the regular budget, the peacekeeping budgets and international tribunals, as well as the financial statements of the Organization. The Controller advises the Secretary-General and the Under-Secretary-General for Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance on policy relating to the budgets and finances of the United Nations and the related plans and work programmes. Through the Office of Programme Planning, Finance and Budget, the Controller ensures that the financial policy framework enables efficient mandate delivery. The Director of the Finance Division, in addition to existing responsibilities under subprogramme 2, component 1, supports the Controller directly with regard to overseeing cross-cutting functions, such as financial policy and the Committee on Contributions, and deputizes for the Controller on all financial policies relating to United Nations system entities and other partners of the Secretariat. As the Deputy Controller, the Director of the Finance Division enables appropriate burden-sharing with the Controller in addressing matters relating to complex and critical financial management in a proactive manner.

29A.158	The Assistant Secretary-General for Human Resources leverages technologies and pursues innovative and holistic approaches to transform the organizational culture, strengthen duty of care, promote inclusion, accessibility and workforce diversity, and drive the creation of a supportive and healthy workplace. The Office of Human Resources responds proactively to issues arising in the formal and informal system of administration of justice to ensure the efficient, effective and fair implementation of the Organization’s policies, core values and norms. It builds on the integration of the conduct and discipline function for the entire Secretariat and for all categories of personnel to increase consistency, transparency and accountability in the application of the standards of conduct.

29A.159	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Department is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. In line with its functional responsibilities, the Department will continue to mainstream environmental sustainability management into the Secretariat policy framework and the enterprise management and accountability system. Operationally the Department will continue to prioritize the reduction in its travel-related greenhouse gas emissions by optimizing the use of online collaborative and conferencing platforms, as well as streamlining and combining travel requirements.

29A.160	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 29A.45. The Department will continue to implement measures to improve compliance rates with the advance purchase of air tickets through the earlier planning of events and nominations of travellers, raising the awareness of programme managers and travellers and minimizing exceptions. In 2024, the Department continued to submit nearly all of its documents within the prescribed timelines.

text: Annex II Summary of proposed post changes, by component and subprogramme

table_content.text: Conversion from temporary positions of 1 Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5), 1 Management and Programme Analyst (P-4) and 1 Administrative Assistant (GS (OL))

The proposed conversion of 3 general temporary assistance positions (1 P-5, 1 P-4 and 1 GS (OL)) to posts would provide long-term stability in the execution of essential functions in support of the work of the Sustainability and Resilience Management Section. Lessons learned from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as from other locally isolated emergencies, confirm the importance of having organization-wide mature and up-to-date continuity planning, with personnel and infrastructure ready to support the ongoing implementation of Member States’ mandates. The conversion of the positions, which were initially created in 2008 (P-5), 2010 (GS (OL)) and 2011 (P-4), is proposed given the long-term and core nature of the functions performed by the incumbents of these positions, including as indicated below.
The Senior Programme Management Officer will continue to coordinate cross-cutting strategy and policy matters relating to continuity of functions and new ways of working, with a particular emphasis on areas relating to procurement, human resources and linkages to accountability matters in coordination with the Business Transformation and Accountability Division, the Office of Human Resources and the Office of Programme Planning, Finance and Budget. The incumbent coordinates specialized policy support, to ensure that new policies and changes take into account business continuity matters and are implemented in a timely and holistic manner, utilizing a continuous improvement approach by responding to changing conditions and taking advantage of evolving opportunities and applying lessons learned.
The continuation and conversion of the Management and Programme Analyst position is critical to supporting the business continuity planning efforts of Secretariat entities and overall coordination across the global Secretariat, including the sharing of best practices and lessons learned. The functions include guidance and training for continuity planning of the critical functions of the Organization, assistance to entities with the conduct of simulation exercises for practising and testing their continuity plans, and ensuring a coordinated approach across entities. The incumbent, as part of the Sustainability and Resilience Management Section, serves as secretariat to the Senior Emergency Policy Team at United Nations Headquarters. The incumbent also provides functional support in the area of business continuity management to the Headquarters Crisis Operations Group.
The continuation and conversion of the Administrative Assistant position is required to provide administrative and logistical support to the Section and will develop and maintain collaborative sites on SharePoint and Microsoft Teams to ensure that the various working groups and communities of practice are active and kept well informed.
Conversion from temporary positions of 1 Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5), 1 Management and Programme Analyst (P-4) and 1 Administrative Assistant (GS (OL))

The proposed conversion of 3 general temporary assistance positions (1 P-5, 1 P-4 and 1 GS (OL)) to posts would provide long-term stability in the execution of essential functions in support of the work of the Sustainability and Resilience Management Section. Lessons learned from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as from other locally isolated emergencies, confirm the importance of having organization-wide mature and up-to-date continuity planning, with personnel and infrastructure ready to support the ongoing implementation of Member States’ mandates. The conversion of the positions, which were initially created in 2008 (P-5), 2010 (GS (OL)) and 2011 (P-4), is proposed given the long-term and core nature of the functions performed by the incumbents of these positions, including as indicated below.
The Senior Programme Management Officer will continue to coordinate cross-cutting strategy and policy matters relating to continuity of functions and new ways of working, with a particular emphasis on areas relating to procurement, human resources and linkages to accountability matters in coordination with the Business Transformation and Accountability Division, the Office of Human Resources and the Office of Programme Planning, Finance and Budget. The incumbent coordinates specialized policy support, to ensure that new policies and changes take into account business continuity matters and are implemented in a timely and holistic manner, utilizing a continuous improvement approach by responding to changing conditions and taking advantage of evolving opportunities and applying lessons learned.
The continuation and conversion of the Management and Programme Analyst position is critical to supporting the business continuity planning efforts of Secretariat entities and overall coordination across the global Secretariat, including the sharing of best practices and lessons learned. The functions include guidance and training for continuity planning of the critical functions of the Organization, assistance to entities with the conduct of simulation exercises for practising and testing their continuity plans, and ensuring a coordinated approach across entities. The incumbent, as part of the Sustainability and Resilience Management Section, serves as secretariat to the Senior Emergency Policy Team at United Nations Headquarters. The incumbent also provides functional support in the area of business continuity management to the Headquarters Crisis Operations Group.
The continuation and conversion of the Administrative Assistant position is required to provide administrative and logistical support to the Section and will develop and maintain collaborative sites on SharePoint and Microsoft Teams to ensure that the various working groups and communities of practice are active and kept well informed.
Conversion from temporary positions of 1 Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5), 1 Management and Programme Analyst (P-4) and 1 Administrative Assistant (GS (OL))

The proposed conversion of 3 general temporary assistance positions (1 P-5, 1 P-4 and 1 GS (OL)) to posts would provide long-term stability in the execution of essential functions in support of the work of the Sustainability and Resilience Management Section. Lessons learned from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as from other locally isolated emergencies, confirm the importance of having organization-wide mature and up-to-date continuity planning, with personnel and infrastructure ready to support the ongoing implementation of Member States’ mandates. The conversion of the positions, which were initially created in 2008 (P-5), 2010 (GS (OL)) and 2011 (P-4), is proposed given the long-term and core nature of the functions performed by the incumbents of these positions, including as indicated below.
The Senior Programme Management Officer will continue to coordinate cross-cutting strategy and policy matters relating to continuity of functions and new ways of working, with a particular emphasis on areas relating to procurement, human resources and linkages to accountability matters in coordination with the Business Transformation and Accountability Division, the Office of Human Resources and the Office of Programme Planning, Finance and Budget. The incumbent coordinates specialized policy support, to ensure that new policies and changes take into account business continuity matters and are implemented in a timely and holistic manner, utilizing a continuous improvement approach by responding to changing conditions and taking advantage of evolving opportunities and applying lessons learned.
The continuation and conversion of the Management and Programme Analyst position is critical to supporting the business continuity planning efforts of Secretariat entities and overall coordination across the global Secretariat, including the sharing of best practices and lessons learned. The functions include guidance and training for continuity planning of the critical functions of the Organization, assistance to entities with the conduct of simulation exercises for practising and testing their continuity plans, and ensuring a coordinated approach across entities. The incumbent, as part of the Sustainability and Resilience Management Section, serves as secretariat to the Senior Emergency Policy Team at United Nations Headquarters. The incumbent also provides functional support in the area of business continuity management to the Headquarters Crisis Operations Group.
The continuation and conversion of the Administrative Assistant position is required to provide administrative and logistical support to the Section and will develop and maintain collaborative sites on SharePoint and Microsoft Teams to ensure that the various working groups and communities of practice are active and kept well informed.
Conversion from temporary position of 1 Legal Officer (P-4)

The Legal Officer position, initially created in 2008, supports the Section’s capacity to address its heavy caseload and conduct the evaluation process in each case in an objective and impartial manner. As part of an often very time-consuming process, the Legal Officer conducts extensive legal research to ensure the accuracy and quality of the Section’s legal analyses and avoid unnecessary litigation. The Legal Officer spends a significant amount of time gathering information and verifying facts, as well as holding the policy discussions required to ensure the integrity of the Section’s recommendations.
The conversion of the Legal Officer position to a post is requested given the high volume of requests submitted to the Section for evaluation each year (853 cases on average).
Conversion from extrabudgetary resources of 1 post of Chief of Service (D-1)

Pursuant to the observations and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions in its letters to the Secretary-General, the Secretariat proposes the regularization of one post of Chief of Service (D-1) in the Finance Division of the Office of Programme Planning, Finance and Budget. As noted by the Advisory Committee, cost recovery, liquidity management and contributions are ongoing, core functions of the Organization, which should be funded from the regular budget.
The principal role and responsibilities of the Chief of Service are to act as Secretary of the Committee on Contributions, which supports Member States in managing their assessed contributions to the Organization. The Chief of Service acts as principal interlocutor with Member States to address sensitive concerns and challenges and to liaise with the United Nations Treasury and the Controller to resolve issues and optimize the financial position of Member States with respect to the United Nations. 
The Chief of Service also oversees other revenue-generating activities, including global cost-recovery operations and other ad hoc initiatives jointly funded with United Nations agencies, funds and programmes not covered by section 31 of the programme budget. 
In respect of the Chief of Service’s role and responsibilities, it should be noted that the Committee on Contributions is one of the subsidiary organs of the General Assembly, and that the secretaries of such bodies are consistently positioned at the Director level. The Chief of Service is pivotal in developing measures to tackle the systemic liquidity challenges faced by the Organization to safeguard its financial health. Cost-recovery arrangements in the Secretariat continue to grow in value and complexity, encompassing a vast range of services (more than 3,000) and over 75 service providers. In recent years, the changing operational environment and the Organization’s increasing use of cost recovery as a financing model for several activities have highlighted the need to ensure that cost recovery is based on consistent principles, and that it applies approved methodologies, uses processes that are compliant with the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations and conforms to good practices that are generally accepted for such activities.
Subprogramme 2, component 3, Programme planning and budgeting
Reassignment of 1 post of Programme Budget Officer to Data Specialist (P-4) and 1 post of Finance and Budget Assistant to Data Analysis Assistant (GS (OL))

In line with the implementation of the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere, and his vision to transform the United Nations into a fully data-driven Organization, it is proposed to reassign two posts to strengthen the data analytics capabilities of the Policy Coordination Unit of the Programme Planning and Budget Division and align the data-focused positions. The reassignment of one P-4 post and one GS (OL) post would allow the Division to make gains in efficiency and effectiveness by streamlining and enhancing cross-cutting data analysis applicable to all budget sections and strengthening support to client entities on how to best leverage data products, including corporate dashboards.
Subprogramme 2, component 3, Programme planning and budgeting
Reassignment of 1 post of Programme Budget Officer to Data Specialist (P-4) and 1 post of Finance and Budget Assistant to Data Analysis Assistant (GS (OL))

In line with the implementation of the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere, and his vision to transform the United Nations into a fully data-driven Organization, it is proposed to reassign two posts to strengthen the data analytics capabilities of the Policy Coordination Unit of the Programme Planning and Budget Division and align the data-focused positions. The reassignment of one P-4 post and one GS (OL) post would allow the Division to make gains in efficiency and effectiveness by streamlining and enhancing cross-cutting data analysis applicable to all budget sections and strengthening support to client entities on how to best leverage data products, including corporate dashboards.
Conversion from temporary position of one Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5)

The Senior Programme Management Officer in the Conduct and Discipline Service serves as the focal point for addressing policy and other related matters associated with the Organization’s response to issues of sexual harassment, a long-standing matter that requires dedicated leadership and advocacy to promote and sustain the Organization’s efforts to prevent it from occurring. The incumbent supports the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Resources and the Under-Secretary-General for Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance, coordinating with stakeholders on sexual harassment-related matters to lead the Secretariat’s contribution to overall inter-agency efforts on this matter. This includes, but is not limited to, raising awareness, improving reporting and enhancing policies, especially to address victims’ concerns about coming forward with complaints. The incumbent also deals with policy aspects of ClearCheck, including its expansion to other types of misconduct and its full use by all United Nations common system entities. Further to the original purpose of the position, the Senior Programme Management Officer also leads the Organization’s actions to provide ongoing support to victims of domestic abuse and violence. The Officer leads and facilitates discussions on this subject at the inter-agency level geared towards determining a consistent and victim-centred approach, and works in close collaboration with the Office of the Victims’ Rights Advocate to ensure that a consistent approach to dealing with victims is followed. The Officer supports and leads the review and realignment of existing policies and other administrative documentation with a view towards enabling the proactive exercise of the duty of care with regard to those victims. Given the ongoing and continuous nature of the temporary P-5 position, initially created in 2010, its conversion to a post is proposed based on the rationale provided above.
Conversion from temporary position of one Legal Officer (P-3)

The position of Legal Officer, initially created in 2012, primarily represents the Secretary-General in United Nations Dispute Tribunal proceedings, which include extensive contact with client offices to receive instructions on facts, the preparation of written legal submissions and attendance at oral hearings. In addition, the Legal Officer is critical for providing legal advice to managers to mitigate risks in decision-making. This requires hands-on and frequent interaction with decision makers who are accountable for the direction and overall management of the resources of the Organization. Conversion of the Legal Officer position to a post is required because the number of cases handled by the component has remained consistently high and has required an ever-increasing amount of work to meet the requirements set out in the system of administration of justice, including, in particular, the representative functions needed to fully service a robust Dispute Tribunal docket. Given the spotlight placed on accountability and enforcement, the Secretariat’s view is that it is clear that the functions of the Legal Officer will remain fully engaged in this area of work for the foreseeable future, thus further substantiating the request for conversion.
